qas.question: What name is given to the AC component of an applied source having either constant or alternating frequency?
What is one cause of dielectric losses in a capacitor?
What is another cause of dielectric losses in a capacitor?

answers.text: current flow across the slightly resistive supply lines or the electrolyte

qas.question: What is the name given to the amount of internal series resistance needed to add to an ideal capacitor model in order to represent the heat generated by dielectric losses?
What is one type of capacitor that has a specified rating value for maximum ripple current?
What name is given to the AC component of an applied source having no constant or alternating frequency?
What is one cause of dielectric gains in a capacitor?

plausible_answers.text: current flow across the slightly resistive supply lines

qas.question: What is another cause of dielectric gains in a capacitor?
What is one type of capacitor that has no specified rating value for maximum ripple current?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Ripple current<b5_0/><a0_0/> is the AC component of an applied source (often a switched-mode power supply) whose frequency may be constant or varying. Ripple current causes heat to be generated within the capacitor due to the dielectric losses caused by the <a1_0><b6_0>changing field strength<b6_0/><a1_0/> together with the <a2_0><b7_0>current flow across the slightly resistive supply lines<b7_0/> or the electrolyte<a2_0/> in the capacitor. The <a3_0><b8_0>equivalent series resistance<b8_0/> (ESR)<a3_0/> is the amount of internal series resistance one would add to a perfect capacitor to model this. Some types of capacitors, primarily tantalum and <a4_0><b9_0>aluminum electrolytic capacitors<b9_0/><a4_0/>, as well as some film capacitors have a specified rating value for maximum ripple current.
